findings.label: Year-End Spending Pattern
findings.detail: Customer Services & E-Government spent 7.2x their monthly average in March. Note: UK councils operate on April–March fiscal years, so elevated March spending is common as departments finalise annual budgets. Spikes above 3x warrant further scrutiny.
findings.context_note: March spending above the monthly average is expected for UK councils on April–March fiscal years. Compare against prior years’ March figures for meaningful analysis.

findings.label: Benford's Law Anomaly
findings.detail: Digit 2 deviates 6.3% from expected distribution across 27,784 transactions. Note: with 27,784 transactions, chi-squared tests are highly sensitive — the 6.3% max digit deviation is the more practical measure of anomaly.
findings.context_note: Chi-squared values on samples of 27,784+ transactions are naturally inflated and will almost always show statistical significance. The max digit deviation (6.3%) is a more meaningful indicator — deviations under 5% are typical for legitimate council spending.

key_findings.title: SCARAB SWEEPERS LTD: 9675% price gap between councils
key_findings.description: Hyndburn pays £22.3K avg vs Rossendale £228 (both with 3+ transactions) Price differences may reflect different service scope, contract terms, or volumes rather than overcharging — manual review recommended.
key_findings.context_note: Cross-council price comparisons use average transaction values for the same supplier name. Differences may reflect different service levels, contract periods, or purchasing volumes rather than inefficiency. Recommended action: FOI request for contract details.
